item.title: Symmetric Matrices and Positive Definiteness
item.description: 22.1 Symmetric Matrices For a Symmetric Matrix $A$, $A = A^T$. Eigenvalues of real Symmetric Matrices are real and eigenvectors are perpendicular. Any matrix $A$ can be written as $A = S\Lambda S^{-1}$. For a symmetric matrix $A$, this relationship reduces to $A = Q \Lambda Q^{-1}$ as $S$, which is the eigenvector matrix has orthonormal eigenvectors. For an orthonormal matrix, $Q^{-1} = Q^T$ and hence $A = Q\Lambda Q^T$. This is called as the Spectral Theorem in mathematics.
